title: How to Prepare Children for Moving

steps.headline: Count yourself lucky.
steps.description: Generally speaking this is the best stages of moving with children  as they tend to make the moving transition quite well. In the final  weeks before the move they will often pick up on the stress and anxiety levels and could become fussy and demanding.

steps.headline: Plan ahead as much as possible.
steps.description: Give yourself more time to pack, to accommodate interruptions with child care needs. Your child may need more attention than usual and it is common for your toddler or infant to demand it with bad behavior or needy cries.

steps.headline: Find time to pack when it won't be as disruptive.
steps.description: Ask a a family member help out with child care. Try packing during nap times or at night while they sleep.

steps.headline: Keep your routine as normal as possible during these times.
steps.description: Set enough time aside to play with and show love to your child. Keep their favorite security items (stuffed animals, blankets, etc.) unpacked and ready at hand.

steps.headline: This is a great age to move as they tend to express a lot of  excitement, especially when they are involved in some way.
steps.description: They may not  totally understand what is really going on, so you might want to keep the  details simple.

steps.headline: Keep your routine stable and predictable to help with your child's anxiety and stress levels.
Try to pack their belongings last, leaving them their familiar toys and activities to occupy them.
When it's time to pack up their belongings, involve them by  allowing them to place their stuff in the box.
steps.description: You might even let them write their own name on the carton and let them unpack the box at the  new house. You might have to remind them that the same rules apply at  the new house such as no coloring on the walls, no touching the knobs on  the stove, etc.

steps.headline: By now your child has good knowledge of loss and discovering new.
steps.description: Often this age child is eager to help in the planning process and enjoy  being included in the planning stages as well as the entire process.

steps.headline: Use their eager enthusiasm to create a list in their bedroom of items they would like to donate or throw away.
steps.description: It will keep them busy and  productive.

steps.headline: Encourage them to help in many ways, such as box labeling, taping  cartons, bringing you items to be packed, and spending time with the family pet.
Once you decide your new location, take your child to his/her new school for a tour.
steps.description: Point out familiar places like the bathrooms, cafeteria, library, the gymnasium. Finally, taking a family walk around the neighborhood with him/her will get them accustomed to the new houses and people in their new neighborhood. This may present a perfect opportunity to point out places and things that seem to be unsafe for your child.

steps.headline: This is the most difficult age for relocating to a new location.
steps.description: They have made some pretty good friends and have created some meaningful social groups. They have formed some tight bonds with teachers, neighbors, and may have developed a romantic relationship. Although they are mature enough to understand the reasons for the relocation, they might not accept it or be prepared emotionally to leave their friends  and their status. There is no doubt, moving can very difficult at this age.

steps.headline: Tell teens about the move as soon as you're certain.
steps.description: Many parents postpone telling their teens they are moving, hoping that it will be a surprise and they will accept it easier but often  that's not the best method. Telling your teens early on will generally make it easier all the way around. This will give them time to process the ideas and prepare for the loss of their friends. Saying goodbye to  their friends takes time and it's not an easy task. Many of them like to do special things together so they will have good memories. You might even plan a moving away party for them with all their close friends.

steps.headline: Visit the new school and talk about making friends and fitting in there.
steps.description: Teens usually have their social skills developed by now and have no problem making new friends but even the most social teens may worry about fitting in with the new crowd or starting over again. Before spending money on new school clothes it might help to visit their new school and let your child take notice of any certain styles or fads that may be new to your child.

steps.headline: Pay close attention to their feelings and concerns without lecturing them or getting defensive.
steps.description: Remember they are experiencing a sense of loss and need parental support. They will be less likely to show signs of anger, resentment or even depression if you support them well.

text: Infant \/ Toddler: Count yourself lucky. Generally speaking this is the best stages of moving with children  as they tend to make the moving transition quite well. In the final  weeks before the move they will often pick up on the stress and anxiety levels and could become fussy and demanding. Plan ahead as much as possible. Give yourself more time to pack, to accommodate interruptions with child care needs. Your child may need more attention than usual and it is common for your toddler or infant to demand it with bad behavior or needy cries. Find time to pack when it won't be as disruptive. Ask a a family member help out with child care. Try packing during nap times or at night while they sleep. Keep your routine as normal as possible during these times. Set enough time aside to play with and show love to your child. Keep their favorite security items (stuffed animals, blankets, etc.) unpacked and ready at hand. Preschooler \/ kindergartner: This is a great age to move as they tend to express a lot of  excitement, especially when they are involved in some way. They may not  totally understand what is really going on, so you might want to keep the  details simple. Keep your routine stable and predictable to help with your child's anxiety and stress levels.  Try to pack their belongings last, leaving them their familiar toys and activities to occupy them.  When it's time to pack up their belongings, involve them by  allowing them to place their stuff in the box. You might even let them write their own name on the carton and let them unpack the box at the  new house. You might have to remind them that the same rules apply at  the new house such as no coloring on the walls, no touching the knobs on  the stove, etc. Young School-Aged Children: By now your child has good knowledge of loss and discovering new. Often this age child is eager to help in the planning process and enjoy  being included in the planning stages as well as the entire process. Use their eager enthusiasm to create a list in their bedroom of items they would like to donate or throw away. It will keep them busy and  productive. Encourage them to help in many ways, such as box labeling, taping  cartons, bringing you items to be packed, and spending time with the family pet.  Once you decide your new location, take your child to his/her new school for a tour. Point out familiar places like the bathrooms, cafeteria, library, the gymnasium. Finally, taking a family walk around the neighborhood with him/her will get them accustomed to the new houses and people in their new neighborhood. This may present a perfect opportunity to point out places and things that seem to be unsafe for your child. Teens: This is the most difficult age for relocating to a new location. They have made some pretty good friends and have created some meaningful social groups. They have formed some tight bonds with teachers, neighbors, and may have developed a romantic relationship. Although they are mature enough to understand the reasons for the relocation, they might not accept it or be prepared emotionally to leave their friends  and their status. There is no doubt, moving can very difficult at this age. Tell teens about the move as soon as you're certain. Many parents postpone telling their teens they are moving, hoping that it will be a surprise and they will accept it easier but often  that's not the best method. Telling your teens early on will generally make it easier all the way around. This will give them time to process the ideas and prepare for the loss of their friends. Saying goodbye to  their friends takes time and it's not an easy task. Many of them like to do special things together so they will have good memories. You might even plan a moving away party for them with all their close friends. Visit the new school and talk about making friends and fitting in there. Teens usually have their social skills developed by now and have no problem making new friends but even the most social teens may worry about fitting in with the new crowd or starting over again. Before spending money on new school clothes it might help to visit their new school and let your child take notice of any certain styles or fads that may be new to your child. Pay close attention to their feelings and concerns without lecturing them or getting defensive. Remember they are experiencing a sense of loss and need parental support. They will be less likely to show signs of anger, resentment or even depression if you support them well.
